comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: IMO, an elegant solution should be one that can be stated very concisely. Openscad doesn't have a way to load font data from within itself, and the shapes of arabic numerals cannot be procedurally generated in any way that doesn't amount to painting with polygons.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: I see.  Yes, there are two things I could see OpenScad doing.  1) give the ability to read from files.  2) Have fonts as a first class citizen.  I'd love to be able to place a 3D character as easily as I place a cube.  OpenScad, integrated with FreeType, should make this an interesting thing to do.  It could either be done as bitmaps that are linear extruded, or something more interesting than that.

Those are vibration dampers for 3030 aluminum extrusions, specially designed for Scalar family 3D printers.
• 18th december: Add link to the demo video

• print at least 3 of them (4 are of course better), and place them under your printer chassis.
    Each model has a M6 screw hole so that you can use M6X12mm + TNuts to hold them in place
  • place tennis balls under the feets

• Reduces noise
  • Reduces low frequecy vibrations
  • Slightly increase print quality
  • Give you moree space to use under the printer (for tools ....)
  • Fun to use

We provide here 2 models:
  • Scalar -Tennis_Ball_Damper.stl: base model, very steady, the tennis balls will have a lot of surface to stick to.
  • Scalar -Tennis_Ball_Damper_simple.stl: Lightweight version that is 30mm wide and will perfectly fit the extrusion profiles edges.

Here is a video of demo : https://youtu.be/63PycTgbg78 All models where designed using Design Spark mecanical, and all the original cad files are included. Enjoy! 3D Modular Systems

description.text:
17 Aug 2013 I decided to start from scratch and create a more concise compact extruder with better mounting, and which has the SCAD centered on the point where the gears pinch the filament, so it can be customized more easily. Check it out at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:135368 for comparison. I started with the Compact Extruder modified by http://www.thingiverse.com/misan for the 2engineers.com 50:1 Geared Stepper Motor (42BYG48HJ50). I then made the following additions:
  • More tunable parameters
  • An option to draw the assembled parts
  • Minimized extruder option (extraptor_v2)
  • Hinged Idler option
  • Idler axle offset
  • Adapter for the i3 "mini" x-carriage, inverted
  • Hinged fan mount. Angle up for ABS, down for PLA.
  • Fan duct attachment to concentrate air on the hot end
  • Universal GT2 x-carriage, with 24 to 30mm holes, plus top "mini" hole
    • The included adapter is designed for the T-shaped "mini" x-carriage in the inverted position. (The bottom screw holes in the adapter line up with the center of the x-carriage.) I prefer this setup because it allows the extruder to be mounted higher up. It should be relatively easy to modify the mounting included here for your particular x-carriage, but for convenience I've added a "universal" GT2 x-carriage that accepts components with 24mm or 30mm-spaced mounting holes. It has a top mounting hole positioned just like the inverted-T "mini" x-carriage, useful to stabilize an extruder mounted higher up. I recently installed this x-carriage on my i3 and it works great with my existing "inverted-T" components. The official Github project page for this extruder is at https://github.com/thinkyhead/Prusa3 Hot extruder action at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xWZupcYYGX8

This design follows the same approach as my i3 Wade Adapter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58451, using a pair of long M3 bolts through the back that reinforce the platform and provide a mounting point for the front hot-end clamp. Assembly

  • Print the parts, then connect them in the following order:

  • First: Insert the idler nuts into the extruder body.
  • Attach the motor with 2x M3x25mm bolts
  • Add an M8 axle (grub or print) and 608 bearing to the idler.
  • Hinged idler? Attach with an M3 bolt or piece of 3mm filament.
  • Add idler bolts, 2x or 4x M3x30mm (or longer, with springs).
  • Put two M3x45mm bolts through the back of the adapter
  • Attach the adapter to the x-carriage with 3x M3 bolts.
  • Slide the extruder onto the long bolts.
  • Insert the hot end into the extruder.
  • Slide the clamp onto the long bolts.
  • 40mm fan? Add a 25mm bolt, slide onto the long bolts.
  • Add washers and nuts to secure the clamp.
  • Attach the fan to the fan mount.
    • Customizing the SCAD

  • Set __extraptor_v2 = true__ to make the newer extruder, or set it to false to get the original extruder and my custom mounting parts. There are lots of parameters to tune, but the defaults should be fine for MK7 and compatible filament gears.

    • Use the filament_path_offset parameter to move the filament path. Increasing this number moves it farther away from the MK7 gear. The default 0.25 seems about right for the MK7 gear, and 0.0 is fine for the "Raptor" gear (not recommended, see comments). The height of the x-carriage mount is set up for a pretty long j-head (almost 7cm), so that the nozzle tip is about 1cm below the bottom x rod. The platform_y_offset parameter moves the platform or mounting holes down as its value increases. All the parts that will come into contact with the hot end must be printed in ABS (or any higher temperature material). I tried printing some extruder mounting parts in PLA once, and it was fine as long as I only ever printed PLA, but at higher temperatures they warped.

comments.text: You might want to have a look at my how-to , to improve reliability of this motor https://sites.google.com/site/jfpayeur/motormod
comments.author: jfpayeur

comments.text: Thank you for sending me the link! I've been using another technique to keep the output shaft aligned: I stuck a small flat circular disc of metal into the opening at the opposite end of the shaft to keep it from sliding up and down. The disc can't fall out of the hole once the motor is screwed to the gearbox. It will eventually get out of alignment again, I'm sure. Your modifications are much more comprehensive than mine, but they require more tools than I currently have at my disposal. So, as soon as I can get hold of a 5mm ID skate bearing and get into a workshop I will see about fixing it more permanently. Cheers!
comments.author: jfpayeur

description.text:
I have made a little 'suitcase' with some necessities for working with electronics;
soldering iron, helping hands, small multimeter and power supply. To provide a voltage to projects, i use a DC-DC stepdown converter (also 'buck' converter).
The stepdown converters are supplied with 24V so i can can set the output to 1..24V DC. The stepdown converter for this project; search for "LM2596 Step Up/Down DC-DC Converter Power Module With Digital Display" It features a pushbutton which enables you to monitor the input or the output voltage.
I have made a button to go with this case to still being able to operate that button.
Also, the two LEDs indicating 'input' or 'output' are ported to the front of the casing.
I did this using a small piece of 1.75mm clear filament which transports the emitted light to the front of the casing, works superb!
The stepdown converter has a micro potentiometer which should be replaced by a 10K ohm normal pot.
I left the screwconnectors for both input and output accessable for optimum flexibility. On the front panel the output voltage is accessible using 4mm bananaplugs or a series of dupont female jumper wire connectors.

title: Bisect Cube puzzle by Osanori Yamamoto

description.text:
I love designing, making, solving and collecting interlocking 3D puzzles. I have lots in my microcubology shop on Shapeways site but most of them will not print well on current RepRap machines because of the need for tight tolerances and support material for overhanging blocks.
I discovered this brand new puzzle here http://puzzlewillbeplayed.com/553Ring/BisectCube/ at the excellent 'Puzzle Will Be Played' website and immediately realised that it was printable on my new eMaker Huxley machine. It took three goes to get the tolerances right but this version prints just right for me. I have based the puzzle on 10 mm cubes and used a 0.2 mm offset on every face.

Print the three parts and then assemble them into a bisected cube, as shown in the photo. A very nice little puzzle challenge as well as a good test of printing accuracy.
The STL file was exported directly from my favourite puzzle design software, Burr Tools, which allows offset to be specified prior to exporting.

comments.text: Fits quite snugly. I think some chamfering would make this so much nicer on the hands. I'm going to do that manually with a knife right about now.
comments.author: unphased

comments.text: What was the tolerance used between pieces?
comments.author: RosetteHunter

comments.text:
Hi
You may have noticed that the filename is BisectCube_10_0_0.2_group.stl. It takes the name from the Export function in BurrTools, an excellent free puzzle designing program.
The 10 means 10 mm unit cubes.
The 0 means 0.0 mm bevel.
The 0.2 means 0.2 mm offset tolerance.
This was one of my very early attempts at using this program, from a time when my printer wasn't tuned as well as it is now.
I now routinely lower my tolerances figures to somewhere in the range 0.08 to 0.10 mm, depending on the style of puzzle and the printing resolution (fine resolution prints slide more smoothly).
comments.author: RosetteHunter

comments.text: That actually is helpful. I was using this other print to see where my Replicator 2X stands on tolerances: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34038/

author: Mohammadroid

description.text:
This is an after market small (53mm) can holder for a Peugeot 307 that mounts to the fan ducts next to the door.  
I quickly designed this holder as I have found the holders the Peugeot 307 I have are of less than optimal usefulness (many expletives used when my can of beverage spills).  
This Can holder is design to fit a 53mm Can (has a 60mm hole) and mounts in a Peugeot 307 fan ducts next to the door. It may fit other models of Peugeot (no others have been tried). It's designed so the Can will not slip though the holder even if forced at an angle.  
It can be removed but it may require the use of tools to do so. The vertical blades in the vent have limited movement with this holder fitted.  
Note: Not guaranteed to fit any known or unknown car. All I know is that it fits my Peugeot 307.  
Note: Use at your on risk!! (meaning that I assume no responsibility for any events or problems caused by it detaching while driving or otherwise reducing your ability to driver your car safely).  
Note: It's not designed to be removed easily and may cause damage to your car while trying remove it.

There are 4 parts to make and assemble, I glued the parts with Acetone. All the parts key together to help align them. It was printed on a MakerBot Replicator with the following setup: Object infill = 20%
Layer Thickness = 0.2mm
Number of shells = 2 The "Vent_Clip.stl" part must be printed with support because it has over hangs. The other parts can be printed without support and all together.

description.text: I was having issues with the first spool holder I tried for my printer; it was one of those holders where the spool would sit on rollers.  After several occurrences of the spool getting pulled out of the holder and falling onto the printer bed, I decided to create what you see here.  This was designed for a 3up printer, but the supports will slide onto any printer with 20mm x 20mm extrusions for its frame.  Print off two supports, purchase a 1/2" wooden dowel and trim to size, then install.  I haven't had any issues since.  The height of the supports are about 183mm.

author: kuedan

description.text:
Update - 25.09.2016
I have updated the parts as singles. They haven't been oriented for printing. Z-nut.STL mount for the z-screw nuts. Print two, and mirror the second one. X-stop01.STL End stop switch mount for the X-axis. Adjustable. Y-stop01.STL Tab for optical homing switch for the bed Z-stop02.STL Holder for the optical homing switch for Z. T-bracket01.STL T-frame gusset for the vertical frame. Print two, and mirror the second one. Y-motormount.STL Motor mount for the Bed stepper motors. Print two. Z-coupling01.STL Stepper motor coupling for the Z-screws. Print two. X-LH.STL Left X-axis. Filamentholder01.STL Filament roll holder for the top frame. Print two. X-RH.STL Right X-axis. PrinterKit01.stl Complete parts kit for the printer. Elbox01.STL Electronics box bottom. Corner01.STL Corner piece for the frame assembly. Print two. Display04.STL Display holder. Carrier01.STL Extruder carrier and hot end clamp. Extruder01.STL Extruder part. Powercover01.STL Cover for the power supply. Grip01.STL Belt grip for the extruder carrier. Grip02.STL Alternative belt grip for the extruder carrier. Corner02.STL Corner piece for the frame assembly. Print two. bearing02.STL Bearing assembly for the bed. Print four. bearing01.STL Bearing assembly for the extruder carrier. Print three. Fanshield01.STL Shield to deflect plastic cooler fan flow. Print two. Fanholder01.STL Holder for hot end cooler and plastic cooler fans. Corner03.STL Corner piece for the vertical frame assembly. Print two. Extruder02.STL Extruder lever. Stop02.STL Display stop button. Tiemount01.STL Zip tie mounts for organizing cables along the frame. Print as many as necessary. Pulley02.STL Stepper drive pulley. Print three. Pulley03.STL Idler pulley with bearing spacer. Print two. Elbox02.STL Electronics box top. Y-stop02.STL Holder for optical homing switch for the Y-axis. Stepperdummy.STL Stepper dummy if using one stepper on the bed axis. Two steppers are recommended. Y-shaftmount.STL Y shaft mounts. Print four. Z-stop01.STL Tab for the optical homing switch for Z. Y-beltgrip01.STL Belt grip for the bed. complete.STL An almost complete model of the assembled printer.

Here are the parts for my Mammut (mammoth) printer. It has a moving bed, which I was sceptical about at this size, but it works great. The reason I tried a large moving bed was to use stuff I had lying around that would lend itself to that kind of configuration. I now run two motors on the Y-axis for extra power. I will not provide detailed assembly instructions, so don't start building iit if you don't feel that you can do it on your own. It should be self explanatory to experienced makers using the pictures provided. You may need to change some things to suit your part selection in case you don't have/can get hold of the same stuff. Just do it. The part file includes all the parts in one file, so you don't have to download fifty different files. The bed is made from a 40x20x2mm aluminum rectangular tube, split in half along the length, and five 90° angles. The surface is a sanded 4mm acrylic sheet, 800x520 mm. The parts include a holder for a smart controller LCD display (mine was from Sunhokey) and a MKS Gen V1.2 controller board with A4988 drivers. The Newest version is V1.4:
https://www.banggood.com/MKS-Gen-V1_4-3D-Printer-Control-Motherboard-Compatible-RepRap-Ramps1_4-p-951136.html?p=HD240528697332015103&cur_warehouse=CN
https://www.banggood.com/10Pcs-3D-Printer-A4988-Reprap-Stepper-Motor-Driver-Module-p-955808.html?p=HD240528697332015103
https://www.banggood.com/3D-Printer-A4988-Reprap-Stepping-Stepper-Step-Motor-Driver-Module-p-88765.html?p=HD240528697332015103 The pulleys are 2mm pitch. I use them with GT2 belts with no skipping despite being printed:
https://www.banggood.com/10M-Rubber-GT2-Open-Timing-Belt-Width-6mm-For-3D-Printer-RepRap-p-1148503.html?p=HD240528697332015103 The linear bearing blocks take 3x10x4 mm ball bearings. A total of 28 bearings is needed:
https://www.banggood.com/10pcs-623-ZZ-3x10x4mm-Deep-Groove-Ball-Bearings-Miniature-Bearings-p-81182.html?p=HD240528697332015103 The linear rails for X- and Y are 3/4" (or 19mm) stainless steel tubes. I'm sure other rods or tubes in other materials will work as well as long as they are 19-19.05 mm (3/4") thick. 2x700 mm and 2x1220 mm are needed. The rails for the Z are 500 mm long SBR16 supported rails, with four LME16UUOP bearings. These bearings are the 26 mm outer diameter kind, and not 28mm:
https://rover.ebay.com/rover/1/711-53200-19255-0/1?ff3=4&toolid=11800&pub=5575353675&campid=5338226872&mpre=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ebay.com%2Fitm%2F1pcs-LME16UUOP-16mm-Open-Linear-Ball-Bearing-16x26x36mm-for-3D-Printer-CNC%2F263224706711%3Fhash%3Ditem3d496a4697%3Ag%3A3HIAAOSwjL5ZJpBm
Rails:
https://rover.ebay.com/rover/1/711-53200-19255-0/1?ff3=4&toolid=11800&pub=5575353675&campid=5338226872&mpre=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ebay.com%2Fitm%2FLinear-Shaft-Rail-Support-SBR16-L500mm-Rails-Support%2F351705115619%3Fhash%3Ditem51e3422be3%3Ag%3AzoQAAOSwq19XC0DE The frame is made from plastic gussets and 40x40x2 mm square tubing of the following lengths:
2x1300 mm for the lengthwise pieces.
3x620 mm for the ends and top. The ends would benefit from being made from steel instead of aluminum.
2x500 mm for Z. These are installed on the side frames at a distance of 390 mm from the front end gusset, as one photo shows. 2x500 mm long 8x8 mm lead screws with nuts are needed. They will fit into the Z shaft adapters:
https://www.banggood.com/500mm-Lead-Screw-8mm-Thread-2mm-Pitch-Lead-Screw-with-Copper-Nut-p-982941.html?p=HD240528697332015103 I use a chinese E3D clone with a home made Volcano hot end. The fans for the hot end are 40x40 mm for the cold end ccooling, and two 35x10mm blower fans for PLA cooling:
https://www.banggood.com/Volcano-Hot-End-Eruption-Heater-Block-Heating-Block-For-3D-Printer-Accessories-p-1014475.html?p=HD240528697332015103
https://www.banggood.com/Heatsink-12V-0_1A-2-Pins-CPU-Cooling-Fan-PC-Computer-40x40x10mm-p-920618.html?p=HD240528697332015103&cur_warehouse=CN https://rover.ebay.com/rover/1/711-53200-19255-0/1?icep_id=114&ipn=icep&toolid=20004&campid=5338226872&mpre=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ebay.com%2Fitm%2F1pc-NEW-Delta-BFB03505HA-35x35x10mm-35mm-3510-5V-0-17A-DC-Brushless-Blower-Fan%2F221214013657%3Fhash%3Ditem338161f8d9%3Ag%3AgxcAAMXQLbVRaf6C
This fan can fit with some modification:
https://www.banggood.com/Aluminum-Heatsink-Cooling-Fan-For-LattePanda-Matching-Acrylic-Case-p-1092769.html?p=HD240528697332015103&cur_warehouse=CN I use 92 oz in/65 Ncm steppers for X, Y and extrusion, and smaller motors for Z. The 30 tooth pulleys on X- and Y need strong motors, and allow high travel speeds of up to 300 mm/s. A ~11 mm extruder gear is needed:
https://www.banggood.com/2Pcs-MK7-MK8-Extruder-Driver-Feeder-Gear-Wheel-40Teeth-11mm-Bore-5mm-For-3D-Printer-p-1036149.html?p=HD240528697332015103&cur_warehouse=CN X uses a microswitch for homing. Y and Z uses PiBot optical end stops for homing. Parts are included for installing all switches. X- and Z-switch brackets are attached to the frame with high strength double sided tape and provide a large enough contact area to give a very secure attachment:
https://www.banggood.com/10Pcs-AC-250V-15A-V-156-1C25-SPDT-Roller-Lever-Micro-Switch-p-944613.html?p=HD240528697332015103

In 2009, Gerrit Coatzee published this elegantly simple soldering assistant. It is heavy and stable, and it rests on top of an SMD while you solder it. It also acts as a heat sink to protect the part. The device has never caught on, and that's a shame. Part of the problem is that Gerrit made it the old way, by drilling holes in bits of wood like a caveman. So I've updated the design for the 21st century. Here is a printable gravity clamp to hold your surface mount parts. A M5×45 socket head machine screw clips into the head, and three more M5 screws are used to provide ballast. You should sharpen the point with a file or grinding wheel (like a caveman!). In the photos, I'm soldering 5050 parts, so I used an unsharpened tip. Tips are interchangeable. Create a few different sizes and snap them in. The OpenSCAD source file is attached. It should be easy to adapt to different screw sizes, overall dimensions, or head angle.

title: Steampunk Ogre Conversion Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A design from over year ago that I just stumbled upon and decided to dust off. When I found out about Reaper's Bones series (affordable plastic versions of their excellent models) I thought it would be awesome to print a conversion kit to modify this particularly excellent sculpt. You can find the original model at the link: http://www.reapermini.com/Miniatures/Bones/latest/77005 All it takes is a little cutting and gluing (much easier with the Bones material). *Just as a disclaimer, I didn't print the ogre, just the top hat, monocle, belt buckle, shotgun (or "boomstick"), and scenic base.

comments.text:
This mini site is incredible! I am ashamed to say this is the first I've heard of them.
Also, love the steampunk. You just can't beat a classy ogre.
comments.author: Garin

comments.text: Yeah, man! Reaper has some amazing models, and they cover every genre. Thanks, man, I really need to do more conversion kits. I really enjoy doing these.
Reaper makes awesome minis. You made an awesome conversion kit to make Reaper's stuff even better. I approve.
comments.author: Tothe

comments.text: Thank you! I love Reaper's miniature line, and I've been collecting and painting these for years.
comments.author: Tothe

comments.text: I've only been in the hobby for a few years now myself. Started out with the Army painter starter kit and a Reaper Pathfinder dwarf for D&D Encounters. I backed the Bones kickstarter, and definitely want more from that line. I might eventually decide to make some conversion sets myself if anything strikes my fancy.

remixed_from.author: xnaron
remixed_from.title: Filament spooler for Ultimachine/Makergear style spools

title: Upgraded frictionless filament spooler for Ultimachine/Makergear style spools

description.text: I loved the original design, but friction remained a problem for me and my spool wouldn't rotate freely. Turned out the spool's lips weren't quite straight. As a result, the width varied from 103 to 107 mm, and half of the time it would scrape against the sides. This modified version widens the spooler by a few millimeters while holding the bearings such that they can accomodate a spool of between 103 and 107 mm in width without the spool falling off. Also, I didn't see much need for the A-frame parts in the middle which just added some extra friction, so I removed them.

Print. You will need a machine with a build platform of at least 170mm along one of the horizontal axes, so Makerbots are out.
I've also found that lightly sanding the lips of Ultimachine spools helps keep them centered, since some of them have a sharp edge where the two halves of the mold met that can catch on the gap between the bearings and their walls.

comments.text: I measured the 3 spools I have and they are 98mm to 101mm.  I found you need to be careful on how wide you make it or the spool can fall off.  I don't have friction on any of my spools.  I've got some new spools coming and I'll have to pay close attention to the width on them.
comments.author: xnaron

comments.text:
I guess this just goes to show how erratically-sized the spools are. What might be even better is a cylindrical roller that sits on the bearings. Hmm
Ã¢Â€Â¦
comments.author: xnaron

comments.text: Nice mod.  I put the A frames there originally so you could feed filament out the sides.  I'll have to print this one out and try it.

comments.text: clever! a novel approach

comments.text: Can't really take all the credit, really. It's just a slight modification to Xnaron's original. But thanks!

title: Death Star Laser Turret - Lego/Halo Mega Blok Adaption

description.text: Inspired by the Lego/Halo Mega Blok adaption remix of my "Death Star Laser Turret - Simple" done by ICanMakingThings and found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1206626, I modified my "Death Star Laser Turret - Destroyed" thing to use the same adaption base. Since the base of the destroyed tower was nearly the same size I simply blended the bases together into one piece without the need to scale anything. So, the same scale used for the X-Wing Miniatures game pieces can now be adapted to a Lego or Halo Mega Bloks set. Two STL files are uploaded. One with just the destroyed base adapted and the other with a complete assembly of all 4 parts so you do not need to search them out through the remix links. They are Cura scaled and oriented for printing. UPDATE: 5/29/2017 An STL file of a simple short barrel version of the guns has been added to the download files. The short barrel version is interchangeable with the previous guns. Follow the same instructions as the files this was remixed from.

Printer:

Rigidbot Big

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

15% - 20%

Notes: A 5 to 10 line brim will help the small surface area of the first layer stick to the bed. A 0.8 mm shell and top and bottom surfaces seems to work well. A good part cooling fan greatly helps in bridging across the support material. The full assembly prints in around 4 - 4.5 hours. Just the destroyed base adaption will print in about 2 - 2.,5 hours.

Fit and finish The Lego/Mega Blok adaption will be a very snug fit. I recommend that the filament used be calibrated using these calibration pieces found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301. Same surface clean up and instructions apply to these pieces as described in the files these were remixed from.

This script lets you create a positive/negative Data Matrix[1] Bar Code suitable for feeding into your experimental dual extruders. Or if you just want a negative space object barcode to cut into another model. You can encode the whole thingiverse url in your barcode, but the result will be pretty big. Probably too large to stamp into another model. However, you can just encode the Thingiverse thing number to get a pretty small code! 1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_Matrix

Install OpenSCAD, download my OpenSCAD bitmap library, and make sure you have Ruby on your system.  Then run gem install semacode.  Now you can edit the variables in datamatrix_dualstrusionator.scad and .rb and run the .rb script.  It will shell out to OpenSCAD and generate an a.stl and a b.stl.  You'll probably get the best results if you print it vertically.  Note: the bigger the string, the painfully longer it takes.  OpenSCAD is slow.  :(

comments.text: Basically when you have dual MK7s your max X axis build area is around 85mm when you want to do a print involving both extruders.  However, if you want to do just a normal 1 color print, your X axis build area is around 100mm, give or take a few mm.  Y axis is the same either way, around 120mm.  Also, with MK7 you gain a few mm in the Z axis - I'm getting around 122.

title: MakerGear M2 Universal (Left or Right) Spool Holder

description.text:
I'm in the process of modifying my MakerGear M2 into a twin extruder setup as designed by Tim Edwards. Documented here:
http://opencircuitdesign.com/~tim/3d_printer/twin_project.html One of the first things I needed was a second spool holder for the right side of the machine. The right spool holder that MakerGear has on GitHub is too large in diameter to fit spools with a 1-1/4" spindle hole such as Hatchbox. It's also too long at about 4-1/2". I found another spool holder that gets the diameter right but is even longer at 5" This spool holder starts with the dimensions of the currently shipping factory left-side spool holder. It's only 3" long, and is the correct diameter to fit any manufacturer's spools. It has the standard (4) holes for mounting on the left side, but it also has two additional sets of holes so that it can also be mounted on the right side and at two different heights depending on your configuration. Works great.

Do you maybe have some links to resource that explain in brief and well how this orientation tool is used exactly.

comments.author: mechadense

comments.text: It was more something taught in classes and not all textbooks cover it.  I posted a link below to a good resource which is good if you have a background in materials.  The point of the tetrahedron is to show dislocations common in FCC metals with vectors instead of Miller Indices notation.  This helps act as a quick visual reference to show the different possibilities of dislocation movement. That's the briefest summary I can give before I start getting into the weeds on the subject.

Universal holder for filament spools with hole diameter 31 - 58 mm. No need to twist off the nuts from screw rod due to special construction of holder.
Due to very limited space for printer, the only possible solution of spool location was above the printer. The base is made of pieces of MDF, but can be also used plywood or any other material. Holes in the base were cutted by router, hole sizes were chosen based on the dimentions of available bearings. The design was done for M8 screw rod and M8 nuts.
I had a problem with M8 nuts from different suppliers - their external dimensions were differ a bit - so file "Wire holder spacer" compensated this problem. Changing of spool now takes short time, its easy and spool fixed very well. Bearings provide extra smooth rotation of spool and it doesn't occupy place around printer.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

In general no matter

Infill:

30

Notes: There was printed several items with different infill values, but in general no difference between 30% or 50+%. Parts stays hard enougth to hold the spool

This is a Remix of Achoo01's Stunning M3 nut twister http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1091018 I have a similar printer to this persons but the distance between the bed and my slide mounts for the Y axis are much smaller. So I thinned the base of the nut to 2 mm and added a 1mm thick Hex that is 2mm taller to the mount point for the actual nut. I found that the hole for the bolt is too small but not worth adjusting as I can just route it out a bit with a knife and it fits fine. Thank you Achoo01 for making the original nut twisters, Anyone who uses these please let me know how they work for you. I modified these in Tinkercad.

Handle_v2 has a straight handle for uniform cutting action.
Printed with PLA  30% with 4,3,3,3 layers  .
Designed to insert your favorite reciprocating blade for delicate work.  The slot is for 1.0 mm thick blade, although some are thicker. Mark the blade for depth.
It takes some force to tap the handle onto the blade (oil?). There will be a nice round backlit hole when it hits home.   I used a 6/32" x 5/8" or a 3mm machine screw to secure the blade.  A longer bolt an nut can be use.
A file and sandpaper will clean things up and round the edges.

Used to join and separate 1/4" Loc-Line hose (very difficult to do by hand).  I tried the official Loc-Line brand pliers, but unfortunately they did not work with my Chinese knock-off almost-but-not-really-Loc-Line hoses.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

24%

Notes: Printed in Taulman 910 alloy nylon for strength with a little flex. Printed with 2mm walls and top.bottom layers for strength. If printed with sockets for hose facing upwards, no support is needed and you get the best quality on the socket shape.This is how I printed mine. However, if you rotate them so they are standing on their side, then the layer bonding is at it's strongest on the hinge, but you will need support.

Metal bits The hinge uses a 6mm or 1/4" bolt The handles are 8mm or 5/16" smooth rod -- you might need to drill out slightly -- they are meant to be snug. Heat the rod with a blowtorch to melt them in place for an even tighter fit (and avoids splitting layers when inserting them)
The LocLine segment model came from here: https://grabcad.com/library/1-4-modular-hose-single-element-1
